question: Which tendon is primarily responsible for extending the metacarpophalangeal joints of digits 2–5?
short_explanation: Extensor digitorum extends digits 2–5 at the MCP joints.
long_explanation: The extensor digitorum muscle originates from the lateral epicondyle and inserts via tendons into the extensor expansions of digits 2–5. It’s the main muscle responsible for extending the fingers at the MCP joints.
clinical_application: Massage techniques targeting extensor digitorum can help relieve overuse strain in clients who perform repetitive gripping or typing tasks.
text: Which tendon is primarily responsible for extending the metacarpophalangeal joints of digits 2–5?

question: The extensor indicis tendon is specifically associated with which digit?
short_explanation: Extensor indicis extends the index finger independently.
long_explanation: The extensor indicis originates from the posterior ulna and inserts into the extensor expansion of the index finger, allowing independent extension of digit 2.
clinical_application: Clients with overuse of the index finger (e.g., tech use) may benefit from myofascial release of extensor indicis.
text: The extensor indicis tendon is specifically associated with which digit?

question: Which extensor tendon passes through the third dorsal compartment of the wrist?
short_explanation: Extensor pollicis longus passes through the third compartment.
long_explanation: The extensor pollicis longus tendon curves around Lister’s tubercle and passes through the third extensor compartment of the dorsal wrist.
clinical_application: Understanding tendon compartments is important in assessing tenosynovitis (e.g., de Quervain’s) and selecting proper massage techniques.
text: Which extensor tendon passes through the third dorsal compartment of the wrist?

question: Which muscle’s tendon is most palpable along the dorsum of the hand during resisted finger extension?
short_explanation: Extensor digitorum tendons are prominent on the dorsum with finger extension.
long_explanation: During active finger extension against resistance, the tendons of extensor digitorum become visibly raised and are easily palpated across the back of the hand.
clinical_application: Palpation of these tendons aids in assessing extensor integrity and in applying cross-fiber friction massage to reduce adhesions.
text: Which muscle’s tendon is most palpable along the dorsum of the hand during resisted finger extension?

question: Which extensor tendon crosses obliquely from the ulnar side to the base of the distal phalanx of the thumb?
short_explanation: Extensor pollicis longus travels obliquely across the dorsal thumb.
long_explanation: The extensor pollicis longus tendon emerges from the posterior forearm, curves around Lister’s tubercle, and inserts into the base of the distal phalanx of the thumb. It plays a key role in thumb extension.
clinical_application: Massage targeting EPL helps restore thumb mobility in overuse syndromes like gamer’s thumb or text thumb.
text: Which extensor tendon crosses obliquely from the ulnar side to the base of the distal phalanx of the thumb?

question: Which condition involves inflammation of the first dorsal compartment affecting the extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus tendons?
short_explanation: De Quervain’s affects the EPB and APL in the first dorsal compartment.
long_explanation: De Quervain’s tenosynovitis is an overuse injury caused by repetitive thumb motion. It involves inflammation of the synovial sheath surrounding the extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus tendons. This condition is commonly seen in postpartum individuals, athletes, and manual laborers.
clinical_application: Massage techniques like cross-fiber friction over the first dorsal compartment, combined with thumb splinting and rest, are helpful in treatment.
text: Which condition involves inflammation of the first dorsal compartment affecting the extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus tendons?

question: Which tendon is most commonly affected in lateral epicondylitis (tennis elbow)?
short_explanation: ECRB is the primary tendon involved in tennis elbow.
long_explanation: Lateral epicondylitis, commonly known as tennis elbow, involves microtears and inflammation of the extensor carpi radialis brevis tendon at its origin on the lateral epicondyle. It results from repetitive wrist extension or gripping movements.
clinical_application: Deep tissue massage and myofascial release to the lateral forearm, along with eccentric wrist extensor training, are commonly used to rehabilitate this condition.

question: Which massage strategy is most appropriate for treating extensor tendon adhesions on the dorsum of the hand?
answers: Effleurage in the direction of lymph flow
Cross-fiber friction perpendicular to tendon orientation
short_explanation: Cross-fiber friction helps release adhesions between tendon and sheath.
long_explanation: Cross-fiber friction involves applying firm, slow, perpendicular pressure across the tendon fibers to break down adhesions and improve mobility. This technique is effective for extensor tendons on the dorsum of the hand when restricted by scar tissue or chronic inflammation.
clinical_application: Use this strategy post-injury or in repetitive strain cases to enhance tendon glide and reduce discomfort.

question: A client with weak finger extension is most likely to have dysfunction in which group of tendons?
short_explanation: Finger extension relies heavily on extensor digitorum and extensor indicis.
long_explanation: Extensor digitorum is the primary extensor for digits 2–5, while extensor indicis provides additional extension for the index finger. Dysfunction or injury to these tendons can impair the ability to extend the fingers at the MCP and IP joints.
clinical_application: Assess tendon strength and consider soft tissue work to restore function. Postural taping and tendon gliding exercises may also help.
text: A client with weak finger extension is most likely to have dysfunction in which group of tendons?
abcd: B. Extensor digitorum and extensor indicis

question: What is the best palpation strategy to isolate the extensor indicis tendon during assessment?
answers: Ask the client to spread all fingers apart
Ask the client to extend just the index finger while other fingers remain flexed
Resist wrist flexion while the client holds all fingers extended
Ask the client to abduct the thumb against resistance
short_explanation: Isolating index extension activates the extensor indicis specifically.
long_explanation: To palpate the extensor indicis tendon, ask the client to flex all fingers except the index, which should be actively extended. This isolates the extensor indicis action and allows clear palpation along the ulnar side of the extensor digitorum tendon.
clinical_application: This technique is useful for assessing function post-tendon injury or surgery and guiding targeted massage therapy.
